text:
Have tried this out for content on one of my affiliate sites. As Emily and Brett mentioned, it's alright as a starting point but honestly not worth it for anyone serious about content.

By the time you figure out what type of inputs generate the best outputs, edit the copy, piece it together, proof read it, add data/stats, etc, it's faster just to write it yourself. I'm in their Facebook group and people often post examples of blog content they've created with it, and it's usually pretty bland/low quality.

elements.text:

I'm in their Facebook group and people often post examples of blog content they've created with it, and it's usually pretty bland/low quality.

text:
Question about assessing hiring needs.

Our SEO agency is growing rapidly, and that includes the content department that I oversee. Currently, it‚Äôs me and an associate content strategist, who I manage. We have 5-7 contracted freelancers to write.

But now I‚Äôm trying to figure out what the next hire would be, what skills we need, pay, and title (we‚Äôre a new department, so all hires are new positions).

My boss, our COO, told me: ‚ÄúWe want to sell more content services. Do we need to hire more? Figure out what that looks like.‚Äù

But I don‚Äôt have a forecast of actual client work, we‚Äôre talking in hypotheticals.

I‚Äôm not totally sure where to start. What questions should I be asking myself to get closer to an answer?

elements.text:
Question about assessing hiring needs.

Our SEO agency is growing rapidly, and that includes the content department that I oversee. Currently, it‚Äôs me and an associate content strategist, who I manage. We have 5-7 contracted freelancers to write.

But now I‚Äôm trying to figure out what the next hire would be, what skills we need, pay, and title (we‚Äôre a new department, so all hires are new positions).

My boss, our COO, told me: ‚ÄúWe want to sell more content services. Do we need to hire more? Figure out what that looks like.‚Äù

But I don‚Äôt have a forecast of actual client work, we‚Äôre talking in hypotheticals.

I‚Äôm not totally sure where to start. What questions should I be asking myself to get closer to an answer?

text: where are your bottlenecks? if you had 10x as many clients next month, where would the breakdowns happen?

elements.text: where are your bottlenecks? if you had 10x as many clients next month, where would the breakdowns happen?

text: "We want to sell more. So that means hiring more"

elements.text: "We want to sell more. So that means hiring more"

text: That's a huge mistake IMO. Hiring has to come after the increase in pipeline, no?

elements.text: That's a huge mistake IMO. Hiring has to come after the increase in pipeline, no?

text: <@UUXMCJQ15> yes but agencies usually require new employees to come onboard just slightly ahead of new customers

elements.text: yes but agencies usually require new employees to come onboard just slightly ahead of new customers

text: and it can take a really long time to hire. so if you think it's gonna take 2-3 months to hire, your prospects likely won't sit around waiting for you. (and that time doesn't include onboarding)

elements.text: and it can take a really long time to hire. so if you think it's gonna take 2-3 months to hire, your prospects likely won't sit around waiting for you. (and that time doesn't include onboarding)

text: saas companies can usually survive (and even grow) without enough people around to do the work, but agencies become stagnant or even shrink without adding new people

text:
Oh 100%. I saw this when I was leading SEO at Directive and in charge of hiring for a bit.

Maybe I read too much into the initial statement and was making sure I understood the COO's logic.

elements.text:
Oh 100%. I saw this when I was leading SEO at Directive and in charge of hiring for a bit.

text:
> ‚ÄúWe want to sell more. So that means hiring more‚Äù
No, although I can see how you interpreted it this way.

We have a steadily growing pipeline of new clients, and we have some non-content services that we‚Äôre developing and selling, which will eventually mean more work that trickles down to us.

More, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre steadily selling more, and plan to keep selling. How can we hire to sustain + scale growth?‚Äù

I want to avoid hiring in a storm, rather, get in front of it. (Plus I‚Äôm planning to be out on paternity later this year, so, getting more hands hired sooner.)

elements.text: ‚ÄúWe want to sell more. So that means hiring more‚Äù

I want to avoid hiring in a storm, rather, get in front of it. (Plus I‚Äôm planning to be out on paternity later this year, so, getting more hands hired sooner.)

text: There‚Äôs a lot of unknown variables here, so it‚Äôs difficult to give you good advice. I‚Äôd start by being really clear about what you mean by ‚Äúcontent services‚Äù. What do those projects look like? Once you‚Äôve got a clear idea of what you want to sell, then you can start defining what level of seniority/skills do you need to execute them. Then you can see where your gaps are. Right now you‚Äôre using freelancers for writing - would you want to bring any of them in as FT employees? It‚Äôs often easier to onboard freelancers than bring someone in from another organization. Also, if you‚Äôre thinking on bringing on junior employees, bear in mind that they‚Äôll need some training and mentorship - stuff that will cut into your bandwidth. FWIW I‚Äôve spent the last five years at various senior roles at a B2B digital marketing agency that‚Äôs grown from around 35 employees to over 160 in my tenure. I know how hard this can be to figure out - happy to get into the weeds if it‚Äôs useful!

elements.text: There‚Äôs a lot of unknown variables here, so it‚Äôs difficult to give you good advice. I‚Äôd start by being really clear about what you mean by ‚Äúcontent services‚Äù. Then you can see where your gaps are. Right now you‚Äôre using freelancers for writing - would you want to bring any of them in as FT employees? Also, if you‚Äôre thinking on bringing on junior employees, bear in mind that they‚Äôll need some training and mentorship - stuff that will cut into your bandwidth. FWIW I‚Äôve spent the last five years at various senior roles at a B2B digital marketing agency that‚Äôs grown from around 35 employees to over 160 in my tenure. I know how hard this can be to figure out - happy to get into the weeds if it‚Äôs useful!

text: Also, the recommended reading on this is Managing the Professional Services Firm by David Maister: <https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/685405.Managing_The_Professional_Service_Firm> It‚Äôs a not an easy read, but there‚Äôs a ton of useful frameworks for thinking this stuff through (especially his definitions of the three different types of projects).
